column2: AN INVITATION.

column2: It is a curious fact, and makes life very interesting, that, generally speaking, none of us have any expectation that things are going to happen till the very moment when they do happen.
column3: It is a curious fact, and makes life very interesting, that, generally speaking, none of us have any expectation that things are going to happen till the very moment when they do happen.

column2: We wake up some morning with no idea that a great happiness is at hand, and before night it has come, and all the world is changed for us; or we wake bright and cheerful, with never a guess that clouds of sorrow are lowering in our sky, to put all the sunshine out for a while, and before noon all is dark.
column3: We wake up some morning with no idea that a great happiness is at hand, and before night it has come, and all the world is changed for us; or we wake bright and cheerful, with never a guess that clouds of sorrow are lowering in our sky, to put all the sunshine out for a while, and before noon all is dark.

column3: All Burnet took an interest in Katy's plans, and almost everybody had some sort of advice or help, or some little gift to offer.

column2: Old Mrs. Worrett, who, though fatter than ever, still retained the power of locomotion, drove in from Conic Section in her roomy carryall with the present of a rather obsolete copy of "Murray's Guide," in faded red covers, which her father had used in his youth, and which she was sure Katy would find convenient; also a bottle of Brown's Jamaica Ginger, in case of sea-sickness.
column3: Old mrs Worrett, who, though fatter than ever, still retained the power of locomotion, drove in from Conic Section in her roomy carryall with the present of a rather obsolete copy of "Murray's Guide," in faded red covers, which her father had used in his youth, and which she was sure Katy would find convenient; also a bottle of Brown's Jamaica Ginger, in case of sea sickness.

column2: Debby's sister-in-law brought a bundle of dried chamomile for the same purpose.
column3: Debby's sister in law brought a bundle of dried chamomile for the same purpose.

column2: Some one had told her it was the "handiest thing in the world to take along with you on them steamboats." Cecy sent a wonderful old-gold and scarlet contrivance to hang on the wall of the stateroom.
column3: Some one had told her it was the "handiest thing in the world to take along with you on them steamboats." Cecy sent a wonderful old gold and scarlet contrivance to hang on the wall of the stateroom.

column2: There were pockets for watches, and pockets for medicines, and pockets for handkerchief and hairpins,--in short, there were pockets for everything; besides a pincushion with "Bon Voyage" in rows of shining pins, a bottle of eau-de-cologne, a cake of soap, and a hammer and tacks to nail the whole up with.
column3: There were pockets for watches, and pockets for medicines, and pockets for handkerchief and hairpins,--in short, there were pockets for everything; besides a pincushion with "Bon Voyage" in rows of shining pins, a bottle of eau de cologne, a cake of soap, and a hammer and tacks to nail the whole up with.

column2: Mrs. Hall's gift was a warm and very pretty woollen wrapper of dark blue flannel, with a pair of soft knitted slippers to match.
column3: mrs Hall's gift was a warm and very pretty woollen wrapper of dark blue flannel, with a pair of soft knitted slippers to match.

column2: Old Mr. Worrett sent a note of advice, recommending Katy to take a quinine pill every day that she was away, never to stay out late, because the dews "over there" were said to be unwholesome, and on no account to drink a drop of water which had not been boiled.
column3: Old mr Worrett sent a note of advice, recommending Katy to take a quinine pill every day that she was away, never to stay out late, because the dews "over there" were said to be unwholesome, and on no account to drink a drop of water which had not been boiled.

column2: From Cousin Helen came a delightful travelling-bag, light and strong at once, and fitted up with all manner of nice little conveniences.
column3: From Cousin Helen came a delightful travelling bag, light and strong at once, and fitted up with all manner of nice little conveniences.

column2: Miss Inches sent a "History of Europe" in five fat volumes, which was so heavy that it had to be left at home.
column3: Miss Inches sent a "History of Europe" in five fat volumes, which was so heavy that it had to be left at home.

column2: In fact, a good many of Katy's presents had to be left at home, including a bronze paper-weight in the shape of a griffin, a large pair of brass screw candlesticks, and an ormolu inkstand with a pen-rest attached, which weighed at least a pound and a half.
column3: In fact, a good many of Katy's presents had to be left at home, including a bronze paper weight in the shape of a griffin, a large pair of brass screw candlesticks, and an ormolu inkstand with a pen rest attached, which weighed at least a pound and a half.

column2: These Katy laid aside to enjoy after her return.
column3: These Katy laid aside to enjoy after her return.

column2: Mrs. Ashe and Cousin Helen had both warned her of the inconvenient consequences of weight in baggage; and by their advice she had limited herself to a single trunk of moderate size, besides a little flat valise for use in her stateroom.
column3: mrs Ashe and Cousin Helen had both warned her of the inconvenient consequences of weight in baggage; and by their advice she had limited herself to a single trunk of moderate size, besides a little flat valise for use in her stateroom.

column2: Clover's gift was a set of blank books for notes, journals, etc.
column3: Clover's gift was a set of blank books for notes, journals, etc

column2: In one of these, Katy made out a list of "Things I must see," "Things I must do," "Things I would like to see," "Things I would like to do." Another she devoted to various good shopping addresses which had been given her; for though she did not expect to do any shopping herself, she thought Mrs. Ashe might find them useful.
column3: In one of these, Katy made out a list of "Things I must see," "Things I must do," "Things I would like to see," "Things I would like to do." Another she devoted to various good shopping addresses which had been given her; for though she did not expect to do any shopping herself, she thought mrs Ashe might find them useful.

column2: Katy's ideas were still so simple and unworldly, and her experience of life so small, that it had not occurred to her how very tantalizing it might be to stand in front of shop windows full of delightful things and not be able to buy any of them. She was accordingly overpowered with surprise, gratitude, and the sense of sudden wealth, when about a week before the start her father gave her three little thin strips of paper, which he told her were circular notes, and worth a hundred dollars apiece.
column3: Katy's ideas were still so simple and unworldly, and her experience of life so small, that it had not occurred to her how very tantalizing it might be to stand in front of shop windows full of delightful things and not be able to buy any of them. She was accordingly overpowered with surprise, gratitude, and the sense of sudden wealth, when about a week before the start her father gave her three little thin strips of paper, which he told her were circular notes, and worth a hundred dollars apiece.

column2: He also gave her five English sovereigns.
column3: He also gave her five English sovereigns.

column2: Those are for immediate use, he said.
column3: Those are for immediate use, he said.

column2: Put the notes away carefully, and don't lose them.	Put the notes away carefully, and don't lose them.
column3: true

column2: You had better have them cashed one at a time as you require them.
column3: You had better have them cashed one at a time as you require them.

column2: Mrs. Ashe will explain how.
column3: mrs Ashe will explain how.

column2: You will need a gown or so before you come back, and you'll want to buy some photographs and so on, and there will be fees--"
column3: You will need a gown or so before you come back, and you'll want to buy some photographs and so on, and there will be fees-"

column2: But, papa, protested Katy, opening wide her candid eyes, "I didn't expect you to give me any money, and I'm afraid you are giving me too much.
column3: But, papa, protested Katy, opening wide her candid eyes, "I didn't expect you to give me any money, and I'm afraid you are giving me too much.

column2: Do you think you can afford it?
column3: Do you think you can afford it?

column2: Really and truly, I don't want to buy things.
column3: Really and truly, I don't want to buy things.

column2: I shall see everything, you know, and that's enough."
column3: I shall see everything, you know, and that's enough."

column2: Her father only laughed.
column3: Her father only laughed.

column2: You'll be wiser and greedier before the year is out, my dear, he replied.
column3: You'll be wiser and greedier before the year is out, my dear, he replied.

column2: Three hundred dollars won't go far, as you'll find.	Three hundred dollars won't go far, as you'll find.
column3: true

column2: But it's all I can spare, and I trust you to keep within it, and not come home with any long bills for me to pay."
column3: But it's all I can spare, and I trust you to keep within it, and not come home with any long bills for me to pay."

column2: Papa!	Papa!
column3: true

column2: I should think not!" cried Katy, with unsophisticated horror.
column3: I should think not!" cried Katy, with unsophisticated horror.

column2: One very interesting thing was to happen before they sailed, the thought of which helped both Katy and Clover through the last hard days, when the preparations were nearly complete, and the family had leisure to feel dull and out of spirits.
column3: One very interesting thing was to happen before they sailed, the thought of which helped both Katy and Clover through the last hard days, when the preparations were nearly complete, and the family had leisure to feel dull and out of spirits.

column2: Katy was to make Rose Red a visit.
column3: Katy was to make Rose Red a visit.

column2: Rose had by no means been idle during the three years and a half which had elapsed since they all parted at Hillsover, and during which the girls had not seen her.
column3: Rose had by no means been idle during the three years and a half which had elapsed since they all parted at Hillsover, and during which the girls had not seen her.

column2: In fact, she had made more out of the time than any of the rest of them, for she had been engaged for eighteen months, had been married, and was now keeping house near Boston with a little Rose of her own, who, she wrote to Clover, was a perfect angel, and more delicious than words could say!
column3: In fact, she had made more out of the time than any of the rest of them, for she had been engaged for eighteen months, had been married, and was now keeping house near Boston with a little Rose of her own, who, she wrote to Clover, was a perfect angel, and more delicious than words could say!

column2: Mrs. Ashe had taken passage in the "Spartacus," sailing from Boston; and it was arranged that Katy should spend the last two days before sailing, with Rose, while Mrs. Ashe and Amy visited an old aunt in Hingham.
column3: mrs Ashe had taken passage in the "Spartacus," sailing from Boston; and it was arranged that Katy should spend the last two days before sailing, with Rose, while mrs Ashe and Amy visited an old aunt in Hingham.

column2: To see Rose in her own home, and Rose's husband, and Rose's baby, was only next in interest to seeing Europe.
column3: To see Rose in her own home, and Rose's husband, and Rose's baby, was only next in interest to seeing Europe.

column2: None of the changes in her lot seemed to have changed her particularly, to judge by the letter she sent in reply to Katy's announcing her plans, which letter ran as follows:--
column3: None of the changes in her lot seemed to have changed her particularly, to judge by the letter she sent in reply to Katy's announcing her plans, which letter ran as follows:--

column2: LONGWOOD, September 20.	LONGWOOD, september twentieth.
column3: false

column2: My dearest child,--Your note made me dance with delight.	My dearest child,--Your note made me dance with delight.
column3: true

column2: I stood on my head waving my heels wildly to the breeze till Deniston thought I must be taken suddenly mad; but when I explained he did the same.
column3: I stood on my head waving my heels wildly to the breeze till Deniston thought I must be taken suddenly mad; but when I explained he did the same.

column2: It is too enchanting, the whole of it.
column3: It is too enchanting, the whole of it.

column2: I put it at the head of all the nice things that ever happened, except my baby.
column3: I put it at the head of all the nice things that ever happened, except my baby.

column2: Write the moment you get this by what train you expect to reach Boston, and when you roll into the station you will behold two forms, one tall and stalwart, the other short and fatsome, waiting for you.
column3: Write the moment you get this by what train you expect to reach Boston, and when you roll into the station you will behold two forms, one tall and stalwart, the other short and fatsome, waiting for you.

column2: They will be those of Deniston and myself.
column3: They will be those of Deniston and myself.

column2: Deniston is not beautiful, but he is good, and he is prepared to _adore_ you.
column3: Deniston is not beautiful, but he is good, and he is prepared to underscore adore underscore you.

column2: The baby is both good and beautiful, and you will adore her.
column3: The baby is both good and beautiful, and you will adore her.

column2: I am neither; but you know all about me, and I always did adore you and always shall.
column3: I am neither; but you know all about me, and I always did adore you and always shall.

column2: I am going out this moment to the butcher's to order a calf fatted for your special behoof; and he shall be slain and made into cutlets the moment I hear from you.
column3: I am going out this moment to the butcher's to order a calf fatted for your special behoof; and he shall be slain and made into cutlets the moment I hear from you.

column2: My funny little house, which is quite a dear little house too, assumes a new interest in my eyes from the fact that you so soon are to see it.
column3: My funny little house, which is quite a dear little house too, assumes a new interest in my eyes from the fact that you so soon are to see it.

column2: It is somewhat queer, as you might know my house would be; but I think you will like it.
column3: It is somewhat queer, as you might know my house would be; but I think you will like it.

column2: I saw Silvery Mary the other day and told her you were coming.	I saw Silvery Mary the other day and told her you were coming.
column3: true

column2: She is the same mouse as ever.
column3: She is the same mouse as ever.

column2: I shall ask her and some of the other girls to come out to lunch on one of your days.
column3: I shall ask her and some of the other girls to come out to lunch on one of your days.

column2: Good-by, with a hundred and fifty kisses to Clovy and the rest.
column3: Good by, with a hundred and fifty kisses to Clovy and the rest.

column2: Your loving	Your loving
column3: true

column2: ROSE RED.
column3: ROSE RED.

column2: She never signs herself Browne, I observe, said Clover, as she finished the letter.
column3: She never signs herself Browne, I observe, said Clover, as she finished the letter.

column2: Oh, Rose Red Browne would sound too funny.	Oh, Rose Red Browne would sound too funny.
column3: true

column2: Rose Red she must stay till the end of the chapter; no other name could suit her half so well, and I can't imagine her being called anything else.
column3: Rose Red she must stay till the end of the chapter; no other name could suit her half so well, and I can't imagine her being called anything else.

column2: What fun it will be to see her and little Rose!"
column3: What fun it will be to see her and little Rose!"

column2: And Deniston Browne, put in Clover.
column3: And Deniston Browne, put in Clover.

column2: Somehow I find it rather hard to take in the fact that there is a Deniston Browne, observed Katy.
column3: Somehow I find it rather hard to take in the fact that there is a Deniston Browne, observed Katy.

column2: It will be easier after you have seen him, perhaps.
column3: It will be easier after you have seen him, perhaps.

column2: The last day came, as last days will.
column3: The last day came, as last days will.

column2: Katy's trunk, most carefully and exactly packed by the united efforts of the family, stood in the hall, locked and strapped, not to be opened again till the party reached London.
column3: Katy's trunk, most carefully and exactly packed by the united efforts of the family, stood in the hall, locked and strapped, not to be opened again till the party reached London.

column2: This fact gave it a certain awful interest in the eyes of Phil and Johnnie, and even Elsie gazed upon it with respect. The little valise was also ready; and Dorry, the neat-handed, had painted a red star on both ends of both it and the trunk, that they might be easily picked from among a heap of luggage.
column3: This fact gave it a certain awful interest in the eyes of Phil and Johnnie, and even Elsie gazed upon it with respect. The little valise was also ready; and Dorry, the neat handed, had painted a red star on both ends of both it and the trunk, that they might be easily picked from among a heap of luggage.

column2: He now proceeded to prepare and paste on two square cards, labelled respectively, "Hold" and "State-room." Mrs. Hall had told them that this was the correct thing to do.
column3: He now proceeded to prepare and paste on two square cards, labelled respectively, "Hold" and "State room." mrs Hall had told them that this was the correct thing to do.

column2: Mrs. Ashe had been full of business likewise in putting her house to rights for a family who had rented it for the time of her absence, and Katy and Clover had taken a good many hours from their own preparations to help her.
column3: mrs Ashe had been full of business likewise in putting her house to rights for a family who had rented it for the time of her absence, and Katy and Clover had taken a good many hours from their own preparations to help her.

column2: All was done at last; and one bright morning in October, Katy stood on the wharf with her family about her, and a lump in her throat which made it difficult to speak to any of them.
column3: All was done at last; and one bright morning in October, Katy stood on the wharf with her family about her, and a lump in her throat which made it difficult to speak to any of them.

column2: She stood so very still and said so very little, that a bystander not acquainted with the circumstances might have dubbed her "unfeeling;" while the fact was that she was feeling too much!
column3: She stood so very still and said so very little, that a bystander not acquainted with the circumstances might have dubbed her "unfeeling;" while the fact was that she was feeling too much!

column2: The first bell rang.
column3: The first bell rang.

column2: Katy kissed everybody quietly and went on board with her father.
column3: Katy kissed everybody quietly and went on board with her father.

column2: Her parting from him, hardest of all, took place in the midst of a crowd of people; then he had to leave her, and as the wheels began to revolve she went out on the side deck to have a last glimpse of the home faces.
column3: Her parting from him, hardest of all, took place in the midst of a crowd of people; then he had to leave her, and as the wheels began to revolve she went out on the side deck to have a last glimpse of the home faces.

column2: There they were: Elsie crying tumultuously, with her head on papa's coat-sleeve; John laughing, or trying to laugh, with big tears running down her cheeks the while; and brave little Clover waving her handkerchief encouragingly, but with a very sober look on her face. Katy's heart went out to the little group with a sudden passion of regret and yearning.
column3: There they were: Elsie crying tumultuously, with her head on papa's coat sleeve; john laughing, or trying to laugh, with big tears running down her cheeks the while; and brave little Clover waving her handkerchief encouragingly, but with a very sober look on her face. Katy's heart went out to the little group with a sudden passion of regret and yearning.

column2: Why had she said she would go?
column3: Why had she said she would go?

column2: What was all Europe in comparison with what she was leaving?
column3: What was all Europe in comparison with what she was leaving?

column2: Life was so short, how could she take a whole year out of it to spend away from the people she loved best?
column3: Life was so short, how could she take a whole year out of it to spend away from the people she loved best?

column2: If it had been left to her to choose, I think she would have flown back to the shore then and there, and given up the journey, I also think she would have been heartily sorry a little later, had she done so.
column3: If it had been left to her to choose, I think she would have flown back to the shore then and there, and given up the journey, I also think she would have been heartily sorry a little later, had she done so.

column2: But it was not left for her to choose.
column3: But it was not left for her to choose.

column2: Already the throb of the engines was growing more regular and the distance widening between the great boat and the wharf.
column3: Already the throb of the engines was growing more regular and the distance widening between the great boat and the wharf.

column2: Gradually the dear faces faded into distance; and after watching till the flutter of Clover's handkerchief became an undistinguishable speck, Katy went to the cabin with a heavy heart.
column3: Gradually the dear faces faded into distance; and after watching till the flutter of Clover's handkerchief became an undistinguishable speck, Katy went to the cabin with a heavy heart.

column2: But there were Mrs. Ashe and Amy, inclined to be homesick also, and in need of cheering; and Katy, as she tried to brighten them, gradually grew bright herself, and recovered her hopeful spirits.
column3: But there were mrs Ashe and Amy, inclined to be homesick also, and in need of cheering; and Katy, as she tried to brighten them, gradually grew bright herself, and recovered her hopeful spirits.

column2: Burnet pulled less strongly as it got farther away, and Europe beckoned more brilliantly now that they were fairly embarked on their journey.
column3: Burnet pulled less strongly as it got farther away, and Europe beckoned more brilliantly now that they were fairly embarked on their journey.

column2: The sun shone, the lake was a beautiful, dazzling blue, and Katy said to herself, "After all, a year is not very long, and how happy I am going to be!"
column3: The sun shone, the lake was a beautiful, dazzling blue, and Katy said to herself, "After all, a year is not very long, and how happy I am going to be!"
